results.title: Kipling's India
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Alan Bateman and Lloyd Capps
results.brief_description: 19th century author, Rudyard Kipling spent the first six years of his life in Bombay where his father taught sculpture. After schooling in Britain, he returned to India to work for seven years as a journalist before returning forever to England to write full time. Although he never returned to India, Kipling never lost his delight in the romance, mystery and endless variety of Indian life. India formed his imagination and provided his best themes. In this program, Keith Adam retraces the journey of Kipling’s character Kim, to locate traces of the old India Kipling loved, and in doing so exposes us to the fascination of India.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Alan Bateman and Lloyd Capps

results.title: Kings row
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, William Cameron Menzies and Sam Wood
results.brief_description: Kings Row was well ahead of its time, anticipating fifties melodramas such as “Peyton Place” and those of Sirk, Minnelli et al., in its subversive view of small town America. The scriptwriter Casey Robinson takes most of the credit for managing to win the approval of Production Code officials during the repressive Breen and post-Breen years. Incest in the novel is thinly disguised in the film as hereditary insanity. Leg amputation is virtually synonymous with castration. The American doctor-fathers are middle class monsters while positive values are inverted almost exclusively in European immigrants and the working class. Religion rates no mention in a world clearly polarised between good and evil. The young people’s struggle to overcome obstacles is heightened to the point of self parody as melodrama of triumph. Visual design was mainly the work of William Cameron Menzies (who storyboarded the whole film) and cinematographer James Wong Howe. From the novel by Henry Bellamann. Cast includes: Ann Sheridan, Robert Cummings, Ronald Reagan, Betty Field, Charles Coburn.

results.title: Kings of sport
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and Arthur C. Stevens
results.brief_description: Introducing twenty five years of sporting champions, including; Henry Seagrove on land and water; Donald Campbell’s land speed record; John Cobb; TT Races on the Isle of Man; Fred Perry at Wimbledon; Henry Cotton the golfer; Denis Compton and Donald Bradman at cricket.

results.title: Kings' horses
results.creator_credit: Athos Film Productions, Peter Bucknall and Gerald Weinbien
results.brief_description: An historical documentary on the relationship between humans and horses. From the first domestication in pre-historic Asia to the present day.

results.title: Kingfisher
results.creator_credit: Bush Films, Geoff Moon and Gordon Ell
results.brief_description: Records the intimate life of the Pacific Sacred Kingfisher of Australia and New Zealand. The birds are viewed as they progress through a year of life - hunting, diving for fish, courting and mating, boring nest tunnels, and the feeding and care of the young.

results.title: Kingdom of the elephant
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau and Kevin Duffy
results.brief_description: The elephant in its natural environment in South Africa. In the plains below mount Kilimanjaro the elephant and the other African animals roam in their constant search for food. The camera follows the lion, giraffe, rhinocerous, and the always attendant hyena, jackal and vulture on their daily rounds.

results.title: Kingdom of the Crabs
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Glen Carruthers and Jan Aldenhoven
results.brief_description: Christmas Island is home to one of the greatest but least known spectacles in the animal kingdom: the annual breeding rites of the Red Land Crabs. Every year, just before Christmas, an incredible 132 million of them emerge from the jungle, surging across roads and the railway tracks. Inhabitants find crabs in their kitchens, their wardrobes, in fact just about everywhere. It is a perilous journey for the crabs which must be repeated in reverse a month later, as once the business of breeding is over, they trek back to the forest where they remain unnoticed for the rest of the year.

results.title: King Zog and the energy crunch
results.brief_description: A puppet animation in which King Zog learns to use his brains instead of scarce energy. The palace sorcerer shows how to make Zog’s palace energy efficient. Featuring the Bob Brown Marionettes.

results.title: King penguins: a study of these birds in captivity
results.brief_description: In this study of King Penguins in their natural surroundings in the Antarctic, and also in the Edinburgh Zoo, the use of the flippers and feet in swimming are shown by underwater slow-motion cinematography. The birds are shown preening themselves, moulting, courting and mating, incubating their eggs, hatching and rearing their young.

results.title: King Oscar story
results.brief_description: Present the year round activities of a large Norwegian fishing company. The fleets follow the seasonal movements of salmon, herring and brisling; various methods of harvesting fish are shown. Factories near the fishing grounds clean, process and can the fish. The company produces its own cans and packaging and maintains a testing laboratory.
